note_text:
Indication: Mesothelioma susp.
Procedure: Dx Thoracoscopy. 6th ICS entry.
Findings: Normal pleura. No nodules. Fluid evacuated.
Action: 24Fr chest tube placed.
Plan: Water seal. Path pending.

registry_entry.institution_name: Naval Medical Center San Diego, San Diego, CA

coding_review.overall_assessment: Verified thoracoscopy codes. Total Facility RVU: 8.25.

note_text:
HISTORY: A 55-year-old female presented with unilateral pleural effusion suspicious for malignant mesothelioma.
PROCEDURE: Medical thoracoscopy was performed under moderate sedation. The pleural space was accessed via the sixth intercostal space. Detailed inspection of the parietal and visceral surfaces revealed normal mesothelial architecture without evidence of gross neoplasia.
OUTCOME: Complete evacuation of effusion. A thoracostomy tube was secured. The patient was admitted for observation.

note_text:

Technique: Semi-rigid pleuroscope introduced.
Findings: Inspection of hemithorax (parietal, visceral, diaphragmatic) performed. No biopsy taken as pleura appeared benign.
Medical Necessity: Undiagnosed effusion.
Outcome: Fluid drained, tube placed.

note_text: Procedure note for Jennifer Allen doing the diagnostic scope today left side suspected meso. We went in at the 6th intercostal space mild sedation used. Looked around everything looked surprisingly normal no bumps no masses. We sucked out the rest of the fluid put in a chest tube. No air leak really. Sending her to the floor check path in a few days.

registry_entry.institution_name: Naval Medical Center San Diego, San Diego, CA

coding_review.overall_assessment: Verified thoracoscopy codes. Total Facility RVU: 8.25.

note_text: Medical thoracoscopy (pleuroscopy) diagnostic was performed on a 55-year-old female for suspected mesothelioma. Under moderate sedation and local anesthesia, a single-port entry was established at the 6th intercostal space. The semi-rigid pleuroscope was inserted. Findings included normal-appearing parietal, visceral, and diaphragmatic pleura. All remaining fluid was evacuated under direct visualization. A chest tube was placed. There was no air leak and the lung expanded. Patient admitted to floor.

note_text: The patient was brought to the endoscopy suite for evaluation of a suspicious left-sided effusion. After achieving adequate sedation, we entered the chest wall at the sixth rib space. Upon inserting the camera, we were relieved to find the lining of the lung and chest wall appeared healthy and smooth, with no obvious signs of cancer. We drained the fluid that was left and secured a drain in place to ensure the lung stays up.

registry_entry.institution_name: Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Los Angeles, CA

coding_review.overall_assessment: Verified thoracoscopy codes. Total Facility RVU: 31.88.

note_text:
OPERATIVE REPORT: Medical Thoracoscopy with Parietal Pleural Biopsy and Pleurodesis.
INDICATIONS: Malignant pleural effusion staging.
INTRAOPERATIVE FINDINGS: Extensive visceral pleural metastasis observed. Eleven biopsy specimens were harvested from the parietal surface for histopathological confirmation. Due to the malignant appearance, chemical pleurodesis was undertaken utilizing sterile talc insufflation.
COMPLICATIONS: None. Hemostasis achieved.

note_text:
OPERATIVE NARRATIVE: Medical Thoracoscopy with Biopsy.
OBSERVATIONS: Inspection revealed a mass lesion on the diaphragmatic surface. Eleven biopsies were harvested from the parietal pleura for histopathologic evaluation. No pleurodesis was performed.
OUTCOME: Successful sampling.

note_text:
PROCEDURE: Medical Thoracoscopy.
FINDINGS: Significant thickening of the parietal pleura with distinct nodules was observed. Twelve biopsy specimens were obtained. Talc poudrage was subsequently performed for pleurodesis.
OUTCOME: Tissue secured, pleurodesis complete.

note_text: We performed a procedure on Mr. Johnson to investigate possible cancer. The lining of the chest wall was thick and bumpy. We took twelve samples to be sure we get a diagnosis. We also used talc powder to seal the space and prevent fluid return.
